newsitem.title: USA: Apple looking to pacify developers - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Apple looking to pacify developers - WSJ.

text.p: Apple Computer Inc is hoping to win over skeptical software developers by ensuring that any programs they write for its future operating system also will run on the current Macintosh operating system, the Wall Street Journal said.
In Tuesday's electronic edition, the Journal said success of the new operating system, known as Rhapsody, is key to Apple's survival strategy.
The new operating system is to be demonstrated this week at a conference hosted by Apple. It is expected to be released in 1998.

The Journal said there was concern among some software developers that the new system will not be a hot seller. As such, Apple is hoping to persuade software developers to develop programs that take advantage of the new features.

At the same time, Apple is seeking to assure developers that the new system will run on current Macintosh operating systems with hardware that is relatively current and has at least 32 megabytes of memory, the Journal said.
